average_phase_mixing_time: Our determinations are mostly in the range of [0.3-0.9] Gyr, with an average of 0.5 Gyr.
The average time scale for the phase mixing process in the Milky Way disc, estimated from the phase spiral morphology.
The value is given in Gyr, representing the time elapsed since the perturbation that caused the spiral. The range of [0.3-0.9] Gyr represents the typical spread of individual time estimates.
weighted_average_phase_mixing_time: The weighted average time scale for the phase mixing process in the Milky Way disc, estimated from the phase spiral morphology, when using the McMillan2017 potential and assuming circular orbits
The value is given in Gyr, representing the time elapsed since the perturbation that caused the spiral.  The error represents the standard error of the weighted mean.

phase_spiral_extent: We find that the phase spiral extends down to $-1.2,kpc$ in height below the plane (about 3 to 5 scale heights of the thin disc) and beyond $pm 50,kms$ in $V_Z$.
The maximum vertical extent of the observed phase spiral below the Galactic plane, and the maximum vertical velocity range it covers.

The vertical extent is given as a negative value in kpc, and the velocity range is given in km/s. It represents how far the observed structure deviates from the Galactic plane in terms of height and velocity.
phase_spiral_radial_range: We detect the phase spiral from 6 to 11 kpc from the Galactic centre and find signatures of vertical asymmetries 1-2 kpc beyond this range.
The range of Galactocentric radii over which the phase spiral is observed.

The values are given in kpc, representing the distance from the center of the Milky Way. The 'signatures of vertical asymmetries' suggests the spiral structure may be less defined or more difficult to identify beyond the specified range.
azimuthal_variation_slopes: In order to quantify these variations, we measure the slope of the crossings zc{}  as a function of $phi$ and find -0.006, -0.004, and 0.002 kpc/deg  for the crossings at 0.8, 0.3, and -0.6, respectively.
The rate of change of the vertical height (Z coordinate) of the phase spiral as a function of azimuth at the solar radius where the vertical velocity is 0, for different vertical heights.

The values are given in kpc/deg, representing how much the vertical position of the phase spiral changes for each degree of azimuth. The statement refers to slopes at specific Z heights 0.8, 0.3, and -0.6, respectively. These values indicate how the spiral's shape varies with azimuthal angle.

description: The phase spiral in Gaia DR3
